content: The "Accountability for Accountants Act of 2002" may be cited as the short title. It includes the restoration of joint and several liability. The "Accountability for Accountants Act of 2002" restores joint and several liability for covered persons in private actions under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The "Accountability for Accountants Act of 2002" restores joint and several liability for covered persons in private actions under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The Act also includes provisions related to detecting and reporting illegal acts, performing non-audit functions for issuers, and inapplicability to insolvency cases. The "Accountability for Accountants Act of 2002" amends Section 21D(f) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, including provisions on detecting illegal acts and non-audit functions. The Act also excludes certain cases from liability if the issuer is insolvent. The "Accountability for Accountants Act of 2002" amends Section 21D(f) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to address non-audit functions performed by auditors for issuers. It also specifies that in private actions against auditors of an issuer's financial statements, discovery and proceedings cannot be stayed. RESTORATION OF AIDING AND ABETTING LIABILITY. The Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 have been amended to include provisions for prosecuting individuals who aid or abet violations of the laws. This includes holding accountable those who knowingly provide substantial assistance to others in violating the laws or regulations. Individuals shall be liable under this subsection for aiding or abetting violations only if their omission or failure to act constitutes a breach of duty owed by them. SEC. 4. DESTRUCTION OF RECORDS; SEPARATION OF FUNCTIONS. Audit Requirements under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 have been amended to include the maintenance of records by accountants conducting audits for issuers. This includes keeping all documents related to the audit for four years after its conclusion, with penalties for violations. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now requires accountants conducting audits for issuers to review potential conflicts of interest and consider divesting from non-audit businesses within 60 days of the Accountability for Accountants Act of 2002. Violations may result in fines and imprisonment. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates accountants to assess conflicts of interest and consider divesting from non-audit services within 60 days of the Accountability for Accountants Act of 2002. Violations may lead to penalties and imprisonment. Accountants must report to the Commission within 12 months on their decision to divest or cease providing non-audit services to audit clients. The Commission will then report to Congress on these decisions. Additionally, the Securities Act of 1933 requires the preservation of records during shareholder litigation. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 require the insertion of the issuer of securities in complaints related to actions taken under the Acts.
